name: services.TextRange

methods.name: operator ==
methods.desc:
The equality operator.

The default behavior for all Objects is to return true if and only if this and other are the same object.

Override this method to specify a different equality relation on a class. The overriding method must still be an equivalence relation. That is, it must be:

  • Total: It must return a boolean for all arguments. It should never throw or return null.

  • Reflexive: For all objects o, o == o must be true.

  • Symmetric: For all objects o1 and o2, o1 == o2 and o2 == o1 must either both be true, or both be false.

  • Transitive: For all objects o1, o2, and o3, if o1 == o2 and o2 == o3 are true, then o1 == o3 must be true.

The method should also be consistent over time, so whether two objects are equal should only change if at least one of the objects was modified.

If a subclass overrides the equality operator it should override the hashCode method as well to maintain consistency.
methods.example:
Implementation

@override
bool operator ==(dynamic other) {
  if (identical(this, other))
    return true;
  if (other is! TextRange)
    return false;
  final TextRange typedOther = other;
  return typedOther.start == start
      && typedOther.end == end;
}

methods.name: TextRange
methods.desc:
Creates a text range.

The start and end arguments must not be null. Both the start and end must either be greater than or equal to zero or both exactly -1.

Instead of creating an empty text range, consider using the empty constant.
methods.example:
Implementation

const TextRange({
  @required this.start,
  @required this.end,
}) : assert(start != null && start >= -1),
     assert(end != null && end >= -1);

methods.name: TextRange.collapsed
methods.desc:
A text range that starts and ends at offset.

The offset argument must be non-null and greater than or equal to -1.
methods.example:
Implementation

const TextRange.collapsed(int offset)
  : assert(offset != null && offset >= -1),
    start = offset,
    end = offset;

methods.name: textAfter
methods.example:
Implementation

String textAfter(String text) {
  assert(isNormalized);
  return text.substring(end);
}

methods.name: textBefore
methods.example:
Implementation

String textBefore(String text) {
  assert(isNormalized);
  return text.substring(0, start);
}

methods.name: textInside
methods.example:
Implementation

String textInside(String text) {
  assert(isNormalized);
  return text.substring(start, end);
}

methods.name: toString
methods.desc: Returns a string representation of this object.

props.desc: A text range that contains nothing and is not in the text.
props.example:
Implementation

static const TextRange empty = TextRange(start: -1, end: -1)
props.name: empty
end
props.desc:
The next index after the characters in this range.

If start and end are both -1, the text range is empty.

props.name: hashCode
props.desc:
The hash code for this object.

A hash code is a single integer which represents the state of the object that affects operator == comparisons.

All objects have hash codes. The default hash code represents only the identity of the object, the same way as the default operator == implementation only considers objects equal if they are identical (see identityHashCode).

If operator == is overridden to use the object state instead, the hash code must also be changed to represent that state.

Hash codes must be the same for objects that are equal to each other according to operator ==. The hash code of an object should only change if the object changes in a way that affects equality. There are no further requirements for the hash codes. They need not be consistent between executions of the same program and there are no distribution guarantees.

Objects that are not equal are allowed to have the same hash code, it is even technically allowed that all instances have the same hash code, but if clashes happen too often, it may reduce the efficiency of hash-based data structures like HashSet or HashMap.

If a subclass overrides hashCode, it should override the operator == operator as well to maintain consistency.
props.example:
Implementation

@override
int get hashCode => hashValues(
  start.hashCode,
  end.hashCode,
);

props.name: isCollapsed
props.desc: Whether this range is empty (but still potentially placed inside the text).
props.example:
Implementation

bool get isCollapsed => start == end;

props.name: isNormalized
props.desc: Whether the start of this range precedes the end.
props.example:
Implementation

bool get isNormalized => end >= start;

props.name: isValid
props.desc: Whether this range represents a valid position in the text.
props.example:
Implementation

bool get isValid => start >= 0 && end >= 0;

props.name: start
props.desc:
The index of the first character in the range.

If start and end are both -1, the text range is empty.

desc: A range of characters in a string of text.
